segments.header: The media, filter bubbles and echo chambers
segments.content: A common critique of social media is that they allow users to select in to "echo chambers" (specific communities or communication practices) in which they are exposed to only a narrow range of topics or perspectives. The second main line of analysis focuses on "filter bubbles," whereby the content to which users are exposed is selected based on a recommendation system. To define knowledge collapse we need to distinguish between a few conceptual sets of 'knowledge', whether or not these are empirically observable. The broadest definition of 'human knowledge' might encompass all the beliefs, information, values, and representations of the world ever held by humans anywhere on earth, whether recorded or not. We also distinguish a third, narrower set of knowledge, which reflects not what is theoretically accessible to humans but which is readily part of human patterns of thinking or habits of thought.
